Knowledge Point: The involvement of a first, second or third person as a subject or object is usually marked with subject and object markers on the verb, except when it is in focus or topicalized. To mark a first, second or third person as topic, a personal pronoun is used in the left-dislocated position (see also \sectref{bkm:Ref403656711} on left dislocation), as in (\ref{bkm:Ref99021532}--\ref{bkm:Ref99021534}).
Content 1: \gsrc cwárè \textbf{éyè} kàzyíː kùŋôrà | \gll cwaré eyé ka-a-zyí̲ː ku-ŋór-a | \gls then PERS3SG NEG-SM1-know.STAT INF-write-FV | \glt ‘But she, she doesn’t know how to write.’
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: To express focus on the first, second or third person, a personal pronoun is used as the clefted element of a cleft construction (see also \sectref{bkm:Ref491333435} on cleft constructions). A clefted pronoun marking exclusive focus (‘only she, no one else’) is shown in (\ref{bkm:Ref496869630}), and a clefted pronoun marking information focus is shown in (\ref{bkm:Ref496869707}).
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gsrc èyí ènjûò \textbf{ndìmé} nìbáyìzyàːkírà | \gll e-í e-N-júo ndi-mé ni-bá̲-a-iH-zyaːHk-ir-á̲ | \gls AUG-DEM.I9 AUG-NP9-house COP-PERS1SG REM-SM2-PST-OM9-build-APPL-FV<REL> | \glt ‘This house, it is me that it is was built for.’

Knowledge Point: Personal pronouns are also required when the first, second or third person is used with a comitative or a copula, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref99021431}--\ref{bkm:Ref99021434}).
Content 1: \gsrc mbùryó ꜝndízànà \textbf{néwè} | \gll mbu-ryó ndí̲-zan-a ne=wé | \gls only SM1SG-play-FV COM=PERS2SG | \glt ‘I’m just joking with you.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{ndìmé} ꜝSánètì Cábòrà | \gll ndi-mé sáneti cábora | \gls COP-PERS1SG Saneti Chabola | \glt ‘I am Saneti Chabola.’

Knowledge Point: Personal pronouns for the second person are frequently used as a term of address, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref99021603}--\ref{bkm:Ref99021607}).
Content 1: \gsrc íwè cìnjí àhò kórâːrì | \gll iwé ∅-ci-njí a-ho ka-ó̲-rá̲ːr-i | \gls PERS2SG COP-NP7-what AUG-DEM.III16 NEG-SM2SG-sleep-NEG | \glt ‘You! Why are you not sleeping!’
Content 2: \gsrc íwè òtèèzé ꜝkúnù | \gll iwé o-teHez-é̲ kunú | \gls PERS2SG SM2SG-listen-PFV.SBJV DEM.II17 | \glt ‘You, listen here.’

Knowledge Point: The comitative expresses a variety of meanings, some of which are captured by the English translation ‘and’. It is expressed by a clitic with the form nV=, where V stands for a vowel /a/, /e/, /o/, or /i/. When used with nouns that can take an augment, the vowel of the augment determines the vowel of the comitative, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref99021991}--\ref{bkm:Ref99021994}).
Content 1: \gsrc nòngwènà (< òngwènà ‘crocodile’) | \gll no=∅-ngwena | \gls COM=NP1a-crocodile | \glt ‘and a crocodile’
Content 2: \gsrc nàkàfùrò (< àkàfùrò ‘knife’) | \gll na=ka-furo | \gls COM=NP12-knife | \glt ‘and a knife’

Knowledge Point: When the comitative is cliticized to a word that cannot take an augment, it is realized as na=, ne=, or ni=. This is the case with inflected verbs, where the comitative is realized as na- in Zambian Fwe, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref476926475}), and as ni=, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref476926486}) or ne=, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref476926495}), in Namibian Fwe.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found
Content 3: \gsrc ndìzyìmáná \textbf{nèndìtóntwêrè} | \gll ndi-zyiHman-á̲ ne=ndi-toHntwé̲re | \gls SM1SG-stand-FV COM=SM1SG-be_cold.STAT | \glt ‘I stand up quietly.’ [lit. ‘I stand up while I am quiet’] (NF_Elic15)

Knowledge Point: With nouns that never take an augment, the form of the comitative is ni=, ne= or na=. For instance, with nouns with a secondary prefix ba- (used to mark respect; see \sectref{bkm:Ref499035982}), the form of the comitative may be na= or ne= in Zambian Fwe, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref99022089}--\ref{bkm:Ref99022091}), and ni= in Namibian Fwe, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref99022109}).
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{nàbàmùkéntù} wángù | \gll na=ba-mu-kéntu u-angú | \gls COM=NP2-NP1-woman PP1-POSS1SG | \glt ‘And also my wife.’
Content 3: \gsrc ndìhárá \textbf{nìbàmùkéntù} wángù nàbánàngù | \gll ndi-haHr-á̲ ni=ba-mu-kéntu u-angú na=ba-ána-angu | \gls SM1SG-live-FV COM=NP2-NP1-woman PP1-POSS1SG COM=NP2-child-POSS1SG | \glt ‘I live with my wife and children.’

Knowledge Point: The same variation in the realization of the comitative is seen with other nouns referring to kinship terms or social relations, even though these nouns do take an augment, such as the noun phrase mùkéntù wàkwé ‘his wife’ in (\ref{bkm:Ref71201279}) and the noun mwânè ‘her child’ in (\ref{bkm:Ref71201293}).
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: In Namibian Fwe, the use of the ne= form with nouns that do not have an e- augment is restricted to a handful of nouns referring to kinship relations. In Zambian Fwe, the ne= form is also frequently found with nouns of class 6 or 12. These nouns take an augment a-, and therefore the expected comitative form would be na=, as in the Namibian Fwe example in (\ref{bkm:Ref436820039}); in Zambian Fwe, the comitative with these nouns is often realized as ne=, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref437511600}).
Content 1: \gsrc ndìbyârà òmùndárè \textbf{nàmàbérè} | \gll ndi-byá̲r-a o-mu-ndaré na=ma-beré | \gls SM1SG-plant-FV AUG-NP3-maize COM=NP6-millet | \glt ‘I grow maize and millet.’
Content 2: \gsrc mùndáré \textbf{nèmàhìrà} | \gll mu-ndaré ne=ma-ir-a | \gls NP3-maize COM=NP6-sorghum | \glt ‘maize and sorghum’

Knowledge Point: The ne= form of the comitative with nouns with an a- augment is not obligatory in Zambian Fwe, though. Both the ne= and na= forms of the comitative are found with nouns with an a- augment, as seen in (\ref{bkm:Ref98512623}).
Content 1: \gsrc òmbwá nàkásè {\textasciitilde} òmbwá nèkásè | \gll o-∅-mbwá na/ne=ka-sé | \gls AUG-NP1a-dog COM=NP12-cat | \glt ‘a dog and a cat’\footnotemark{} (ZF_Elic14)

Knowledge Point: The comitative clitic is phonologically dependent on the word to which it is attached, as seen from its interaction with the augment, which determines the quality of the vowel. Morphosyntactically, the comitative clitic is relatively free. The comitative precedes all prefixes: when added to a noun, the comitative precedes the noun’s (primary) nominal prefix, but also its secondary nominal prefix, such as those of the locative classes 16-18, as shown in (\ref{bkm:Ref437423816}), or the class 2 prefix used as secondary prefix, as seen in (\ref{bkm:Ref437423825}).
Content 1: \gsrc ndìkwèsí njûò mwàìmûshò \textbf{nòkwásìnjèmbèrà} | \gll ndi-kwesí N-júo mwa-imúsho no=kwá-sinjembera | \gls SM1SG-have NP9-house NP18-Imusho COM=NP17-Sinjembela | \glt ‘I have a house in Imusho and in Sinjembela.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{nàbàmùkéntù} wángù | \gll na=ba-mu-kéntu u-angú | \gls COM=NP2-NP1-woman PP1-POSS1SG | \glt ‘And also my wife.’

Knowledge Point: Furthermore, the comitative clitic may attach to any word: nouns, pronouns, infinitives, and inflected verbs. There are some similarities between the comitative and the connective clitic (see \sectref{bkm:Ref492133177}), which is also phrase-initial and interacts with the augment. However, whereas the connective may be targeted by H spread, a tone process that never crosses word boundaries, H spread never targets the comitative clitic. Furthermore, when the comitative and connective are combined, the comitative precedes the connective clitic, as seen in (\ref{bkm:Ref505886208}).
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: One of the main functions of the comitative is to express conjunctive coordination, for instance, of two nouns, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref437512254}), or of two pronouns, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref437512262}).
Content 1: \gsrc ndávú nònjòvù | \gll ∅-ndavú no=∅-njovu | \gls NP1a-lion COM=NP1a-elephant | \glt ‘a lion and an elephant’
Content 2: \gsrc èmé nêwè | \gll emé né=we | \gls PERS1SG COM=PERS2SG | \glt ‘you and me’

Knowledge Point: When the comitative is used with a conjunctive function, the comitative usually appears on the second conjunct only. The comitative may also be repeated on both conjuncts to express emphatic coordination, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref99022262}).
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: The comitative is used with an infinitive to create a consecutive verb form, which expresses subsequent action, as illustrated in (\ref{bkm:Ref71201810}--\ref{bkm:Ref71201812}) (see \sectref{bkm:Ref494204746} on the consecutive).
Content 1: \gsrc àpàpàúrà nòkùhìnd’ òmùzîò | \gll a-papaur-á̲ no=ku-hind-a o-mu-zío | \gls SM1-divide-FV COM=INF-take-FV AUG-NP3-load | \glt ‘He divides the animal into pieces and takes it as a load.’
Content 2: ndàtóːꜝrí cìshámù nòkùdàmá zyôkà | \gll ndi-a-tóːr-í ci-shamú no=ku-dam-á ∅-zyóka | \gls SM1SG-PST-pick_up-NPST.PFV NP7-stick COM=INF-beat-FV NP5-snake | \glt ‘I took a stick and beat the snake.’

Knowledge Point: The comitative can also be used with inflected verbs, which are then interpreted as simultaneous with the previous inflected verb. The comitative may only be used on a verb in the present tense construction; its temporal implications are then determined by the inflection of the preceding inflected verb: both events are interpreted as present if the preceding verb is in the present construction, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref476929407}), or past, if the preceding verb is inflected for past tense, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref476929416}).
Content 1: \gsrc ndìshúwírè ònjòvù nàjwêngà | \gll ndi-shuH-í̲re o-∅-njovu na=a-jwé̲ng-a | \gls SM1SG-hear-STAT AUG-NP1a-elephant COM=SM1-shout-FV | \glt ‘I hear an elephant shouting.’
Content 2: \gsrc ndàbónì bâncè nìbàbùtúkà | \gll ndi-a-bón-i ba-ánce ni=ba-buHtuk-á̲ | \gls SM1SG-PST-see-NPST.PFV NP2-child COM=SM2-run-FV | \glt ‘I saw children running.’

Knowledge Point: A second major function of the comitative clitic in Fwe is to express comitative meaning, roughly translatable as ‘(together) with’, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref99022295}--\ref{bkm:Ref99022299}).\largerpage
Content 1: \gsrc kàbáyêndà nàbàmbwá ꜝbábò | \gll ka-bá̲-é̲nd-a na-ba-mbwá ba-abó | \gls PST.IPFV-SM2-go-FV COM=NP2-dog PP2-DEM.III2 | \glt ‘She was walking with her dogs.’
Content 2: \gsrc ndìsháká èntí nòmùzírìrì | \gll ndi-shak-á̲ e-N-tí no=mu-zíriri | \gls SM1SG-want-FV AUG-NP9-tea COM=NP3-fresh_milk | \glt ‘I want tea with fresh milk.’

Knowledge Point: Fwe can also use the comitative for a type of conjunction called ‘inclusory conjunction’ \citep{Haspelmath2007}. This involves a comitative-marked nominal which refers to a participant that is already implied by a plural pronoun or subject marker. In (\ref{bkm:Ref69997095}), the subjects ‘you and I’ are both covered by the first person plural subject marker tu\nobreakdash- ‘we’ on the verb. The second person singular is expressed again through a comitative-marked personal pronoun ewe ‘you (SG)’.
Content 1: \gsrc mbòtúyèndèrérè \textbf{néwè} kwíꜝtáwúnì | \gll mbo-tú̲-end-er-er-é ne=wé ku-é-∅-tawuní | \gls NEAR.FUT-SM1PL-go-INT-PFV.SBJV COM=PERS2SG NP17-AUG-NP9-town | \glt ‘I will walk with you to town.’

Knowledge Point: Inclusory conjunction involving a full noun rather than a pronoun is illustrated in (\ref{bkm:Ref436905937}), which describes the speaker and his wife; although bàmùkéntù wángù ‘my wife’, is expressed as a comitative, the agreement on the verb is plural ‘we’, indicating that both ‘I’ and ‘my wife’ are subjects of the verb.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Inclusory conjunction is also possible when both the conjuncts are full noun phrases. In (\ref{bkm:Ref489369117}), the noun bàntù ‘people’ is in the plural, and is supplemented by an inclusory conjunct nòmùshêrè ‘and [his] friend’.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Inclusory conjunction is not obligatory. In (\ref{bkm:Ref436906615}), the subjects of the verb are the speaker and his dog, but the verb shows first person singular agreement, rather than first person plural.
Content 1: hàcìtûngù ndàyèndérèrì \textbf{nòmbwá} \textbf{ꜝ}\textbf{wángù} | \gll ha-ci-túngu ndi-a-end-é̲r-er-i no=∅-mbwá u-angú | \gls NP16-NP7-hut SM1SG-PST-go-INT-NPST.PFV COM=NP1a-dog PP1-POSS1SG | \glt ‘From the hut, I left with my dog.’

Knowledge Point: Crucial in determining whether a nominal marked with the comitative marker nV= is treated as an inclusory conjunct is the degree of control by the comitative-marked subject over the action. In the examples of inclusory conjunction in (\ref{bkm:Ref436905818}) and (\ref{bkm:Ref437356554}), the subjects expressed by a comitative are human (ewe ‘you’, (\ref{bkm:Ref436905818}), and bàmùkéntù wángù ‘my wife’, (\ref{bkm:Ref436905937})), and therefore equally in control of the action as the speaker. In the examples without inclusory conjunction, such as (\ref{bkm:Ref436906615}), the speaker (‘I’), as a human, is more in control of the action than the comitative subject nòmbwá ꜝwángù ‘my dog’.
Content 1: \label{bkm:Ref69997095} | \glll mbòtúyèndèrérè \textbf{néwè} kwíꜝtáwúnì | \gll mbo-tú̲-end-er-er-é ne=wé ku-é-∅-tawuní | \gls NEAR.FUT-SM\textsubscript{1PL}-go-INT-PFV.SBJV COM=PERS\textsubscript{2SG} NP\textsubscript{17}-AUG-NP\textsubscript{9}-town
Content 2: Not found
Content 3: \label{bkm:Ref69997095} | \glll mbòtúyèndèrérè \textbf{néwè} kwíꜝtáwúnì | \gll mbo-tú̲-end-er-er-é ne=wé ku-é-∅-tawuní | \gls NEAR.FUT-SM\textsubscript{1PL}-go-INT-PFV.SBJV COM=PERS\textsubscript{2SG} NP\textsubscript{17}-AUG-NP\textsubscript{9}-town
Content 5: hàcìtûngù ndàyèndérèrì \textbf{nòmbwá} \textbf{ꜝ}\textbf{wángù} | \gll ha-ci-túngu ndi-a-end-é̲r-er-i no=∅-mbwá u-angú | \gls NP16-NP7-hut SM1SG-PST-go-INT-NPST.PFV COM=NP1a-dog PP1-POSS1SG | \glt ‘From the hut, I left with my dog.’

Knowledge Point: The comitative can also be used to express an instrumental, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref99022408}--\ref{bkm:Ref99022411}).
Content 1: \gsrc shìbànàkàsírì \textbf{nòbwátò} | \gll shi-ba-na-ka-sír-i no=bu-ató | \gls INC-SM2-PST-DIST-sail-NPST.PFV COM=NP14-canoe | \glt ‘He has sailed with the canoe.’
Content 2: \gsrc kùkànkà ndíꜝkánkà ècìkúnì \textbf{nàkàtêmù} | \gll ku-kank-a ndí̲-ká̲nk-a e-ci-kuní na=ka-tému | \gls INF-cut-FV SM1SG-cut-FV AUG-NP7-tree COM=NP12-axe | \glt ‘I chop the tree with an axe.’

Knowledge Point: Another strategy Fwe uses to express an instrumental is the verbal causative suffix (see \sectref{bkm:Ref451514620} on the causative), which may combine to express focus on the instrument; see (\ref{bkm:Ref489369936}) in \sectref{bkm:Ref451514620}.
Content 1: \gsrc kùhòmpwèrà nènsàndò | \gll ku-hompwer-a ne=N-sando | \gls INF-hammer-FV COM=NP9-hammer | \glt ‘to hit with a hammer’

Knowledge Point: The comitative can also be used to express additive focus, translatable as ‘also’, ‘too’ or ‘as well’, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref99022459}--\ref{bkm:Ref99022462}).
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{nèmùkêntù} wángù nàshwénì wâwà | \gll ne=mu-kéntu u-angú na-shwén-i wáwa | \gls COM=NP1-woman PP1-POSS1SG SM1.PST-be_tired-NPST.PFV very | \glt ‘My wife has also become very tired.’
Content 2: \textbf{nèshúnù} hánù ndìshíní múꜝcécì yáꜝpéntékòsítì | \gll ne=shunú hanú ndi-shiH-ní mú-∅-céci i-á-pentékosití | \gls COM=today DEM.II16 SM1SG-PER-be NP18-NP9-church PP9-CON=Pentecoste | \glt ‘Even today/up to this very day, I am still in the Pentecost church.’

Knowledge Point: Rather than marking the focused noun with a comitative, additive focus can also be expressed by adding a co-referential personal pronoun marked with the comitative, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref99022509}--\ref{bkm:Ref99022513}).
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{néyè} mùkéntù ákùbúːkà | \gll ne=yé mu-kéntu á-o-ku-búːk-a | \gls COM=PERS3SG NP1-woman CON1-AUG-INF-wake-ITR-FV | \glt ‘The wife also wakes up.’
Content 2: \gsrc òmúꜝkwámè \textbf{nêyè} zàkwé zézìzì | \gll o-mú-kwamé ne=yé zi-akwé zé-zi-zi | \gls AUG-NP1-man COM=PERS3SG PP10-POSS3SG COP.DEF8-EMPH-DEM.I8 | \glt ‘The husband, too, his things are this and that.’

Knowledge Point: Another function of the comitative is as a marker of direct speech. It is attached to a personal pronoun indicating the speaker of the quotation, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref99022529}--\ref{bkm:Ref99022534}).
Content 1: \gsrc òmúꜝkwámé \textbf{nêyè} shìbànàrâːrì | \gll o-mú-kwamé ne=yé shi-ba-na-ráːr-i | \gls AUG-NP1-man COM=PERS3SG INC-SM2-PST-sleep-NPST.PFV | \glt ‘The man said: they are asleep now.’
Content 2: \gsrc mwáncè \textbf{néyè} máyè máyè màshènè | \gll mu-ánce ne=yé ∅-máye ∅-máye N-ma-shene | \gls NP1-child COM=PERS3SG NP\-1a-mother NP\-1a-mother COP-NP6-worm | \glt ‘The child said: mother, mother, there are worms.’

Knowledge Point: The comitative can be used to coordinate two identical nouns, giving the interpretation ‘every’, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref99022564}--\ref{bkm:Ref99022567}).
Content 1: \gsrc òmùntù nòmùntù | \gll o-mu-ntu no=mu-ntu | \gls AUG-NP1-person COM=NP1-person | \glt ‘everyone’
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point:
When the homorganic nasal of the basic copula is added to a nominal prefix that begins with a nasal consonant, the homorganic nasal is absorbed by the nasal consonant, leading to homophony between the nominal prefix and nominal prefix combined with a copulative. This is the case for the nominal prefixes of class 1 mu
obreakdash-, class 3 mu
obreakdash-, class 4 mi
obreakdash-, class 6 ma
obreakdash-, and class 18 mu-. For these classes, a simple noun can be interpreted as either with or without the copulative, as shown in (ef{bkm:Ref450640706}) with the class 1 noun mu-ntu ‘person’, which is ambiguous between ‘a person’ and ‘it is a person’. The only formal distinction between nouns with and without a basic copulative prefix is that nouns with a copula may not take a vocalic augment, whereas nouns without a copula do, as shown in (ef{bkm:Ref69997533}).
Content 1: \gsrc mùntù | \gll mu-ntu | \gls NP1-person | \glt ‘a person’
Content 2: \gsrc òmùntù | \gll o-mu-ntu | \gls AUG-NP1-person | \glt ‘a person’

Knowledge Point:
When the nominal prefix begins with a voiceless stop, the basic copula is zero, i.e. no homorganic nasal is used. This is the case for the prefixes of class 7 ci
obreakdash-, class 12 ka
obreakdash-, class 13 tu
obreakdash-, class 15 ku
obreakdash-, and class 17 ku-. The homorganic nasal of the copula is also not realized with the prefix of class 8 zi
obreakdash-, which begins with a voiced fricative. In Namibian Fwe, the nasal prefix can occasionally be heard in these cases. The loss of a nasal before a voiceless stop is not a regular morphophonological rule in Fwe; as discussed in ef{bkm:Ref451507060}, homorganic nasals that mark noun classes 9/10 are maintained on voiceless stops, and as shown in 	abref{tab:2:1}, prenasalized voiceless stops are regular phonemes in Fwe. Therefore the loss of the homorganic nasal of the copula before voiceless stops is specific to the copulative prefix.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: The copulative form ndi- of class 5 shows signs of being extended to other classes. In certain cases, it is used on nouns of class 1, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref492232307}), 1a, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref492232309}), or 9, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref492232313}). This is not an indication that class 9 nouns are reassigned to class 5; as the agreement on the adjective in (\ref{bkm:Ref492236057}) shows, the noun nako ‘time’ functions as a class 9 noun, even though it takes the copulative prefix ndi\nobreakdash-.
Content 1: \gsrc ênì ndìmwáncù wángú ꜝndírìndîrè | \gll éni ndi-mu-áncu u-angú ndí̲-rind-í̲r-e | \gls yes COP-NP1-younger_sibling PP1-POSS1SG SM1SG.REL-wait-APPL-STAT | \glt ‘Yes, I am waiting for my younger brother.’
Content 2: \gsrc zywìn’ ómúꜝkwámè ndìbbâbbà | \gll zywiná o-mú-kwamé ndi-∅-bbábba | \gls DEM.IV1 AUG-NP1-man COP-NP1a-grandfather | \glt ‘That man is my grandfather.’
Content 3: \gsrc ndìnyàmà {\textasciitilde} njìnyàmà | \gll ndi-N-nyama {\textasciitilde} nji-N-nyama | \gls COP5-NP9-meat {\textasciitilde} COP9-NP9-meat | \glt ‘It is meat.’
Content 4: \gsrc ndìnàkw’ éꜝncényà bùryò | \gll ndi-N-nakó e-N-cenyá bu-ryo | \gls COP-NP9-time AUG-NP9-small NP14-only | \glt ‘Just a short time…’

Knowledge Point: In addition to the basic copula consisting of a homorganic nasal, Fwe also has a paradigm of definite copulative prefixes. These have a CV shape and are added to the nominal prefix without phonological interaction. This is illustrated with the class 11 noun ru-tángo ‘story’, with a basic copula N- in (\ref{bkm:Ref505700047}) and a definite copula in (\ref{bkm:Ref438543117}).
Content 1: \gsrc ndùtângò | \gll N-ru-tángo | \gls COP-NP11-story | \glt ‘It’s a story.’
Content 2: \gsrc ndórùtângò | \gll ndó-ru-tángo | \gls COP.DEF11-NP11-story | \glt ‘It is the story.’

Knowledge Point: The copula is used to combine a nominal subject with a nominal predicate, by marking the latter with the copulative prefix. The subject can be a noun, such as bàwáyìsì ‘the vice (leader)’ in (\ref{bkm:Ref450648492}), followed by the predicate mbàmùkéntù ꜝwángù ‘is my wife’. The subject can also be an infinitive verb functioning as a noun, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref506906388}); or a pronoun, such as a demonstrative pronoun in (\ref{bkm:Ref433200018}), or a personal pronoun, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref444602246}).
Content 1: \gsrc bàwáyìsì mbàmùkéntù ꜝwángù | \gll ba-wáyisi N-ba-mu-kéntu u-angú | \gls NP2-vice COP-NP2-NP1-woman PP1-POSS1SG | \glt ‘The vice leader is my wife.’
Content 2: \gsrc òkùhíbà nkúbbì | \gll o-ku-híb-a N-ku-bbí | \gls AUG-NP15-steal-FV COP-NP15-bad | \glt ‘Stealing is bad.’
Content 3: \gsrc àbá mbàrìmì | \gll a-bá N-ba-rimi | \gls AUG-DEM.I2 COP2-farmer | \glt ‘They are farmers.’
Content 4: \gsrc èmé ꜝndónjòvù | \gll emé ndó-∅-njovu | \gls PERS1SG COP.DEF1a-NP1a-elephant | \glt ‘I am the elephant.’

Knowledge Point: A copulative predicate can also be used without a subject. Compare (\ref{bkm:Ref433202231}), where the copulative predicate njínswì ‘is a fish’ is preceded by a subject mbúfù ‘a bream’, with (\ref{bkm:Ref433202262}), where the subject is absent.
Content 1: \gsrc mbúfù njínswì | \gll N-bufú nji-N-swí | \gls NP9-bream COP9-NP9-fish | \glt ‘A bream is a fish.’
Content 2: \gsrc \label{bkm:Ref98775427}njínswì | \glll nji-N-swí | \gls COP9-NP9-fish | \glt ‘It’s a fish.’

Knowledge Point: When a copulative construction lacks an overt, nominal subject, the intended subject is often inferable from the discourse, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref98512641}). The intended subject of njìnênè ‘(it) is big’ is the speaker’s house, a topic which has been brought into the discussion by the previous speaker.
Content 1: \ea | \glll ènjúò yákò njìnénè kàpá ndíꜝncényà | \gll e-N-júo i-akó nji-N-néne kapá ndí-N-cenyá | \gls AUG-NP\textsubscript{9}-house PP\textsubscript{9}-POSS\textsubscript{2SG} COP\textsubscript{9}-NP\textsubscript{9}-big or COP\textsubscript{5}-NP\textsubscript{9}-small

Knowledge Point: The predicate consists of the copulative prefix followed by a noun, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref98775427}), or an infinitive verb used as a noun, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref494182359}), or an adjective, in which case the copulative agrees in noun class with the subject, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref444602411}). Other nominal elements that may be marked by a copulative prefix are demonstratives, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref433201568}), possessives, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref433201646}), or personal pronouns, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref433201795}).
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gsrc òmùsèbèzí ꜝwángù nkùùrìsà | \gll o-mu-sebezí u-angú N-ku-urisa | \gls AUG-NP3-work PP3-POSS1SG COP-NP15-sell | \glt ‘My job is selling.’
Content 3: \gsrc èyî nswî njì-nênè | \gll e-í e-N-swí nji-N-néne | \gls AUG-DEM.I9 AUG-NP9-fish COP9-NP9-big | \glt ‘This fish is big.’
Content 4: \gsrc òbùkáꜝbábù mbóꜝbúbù mbóꜝbúbù | \gll o-bu-kábabú mbó-bu-bú mbó-bu-bú | \gls AUG-NP14-problem COP.DEF14-EMPH-DEM.I14 COP.DEF14-EMPH-DEM.I14 | \glt ‘The problem is such and such.’
Content 5: \gsrc àbá ꜝbámbwà mbángù | \gll a-bá ba-mbwá N-ba-angú | \gls AUG-DEM.I2 NP2-dog COP-PP2-POSS1SG | \glt ‘These dogs are mine.’
Content 6: \gsrc ndínwè éè ndímè | \gll ndi-nwé ée ndi-mé | \gls COP-PERS2PL yes COP-PERS1SG | \glt ‘Are you the one?’ ‘Yes, I’m the one!’

Knowledge Point: Phrase-final tonal processes affect both the subject and the predicate of the copulative construction. This is illustrated in (\ref{bkm:Ref450649453}), where the tonal process of high tone retraction, which only affects the last syllable of a phrase-final word, affects both the head mbufu ‘bream’, and the predicate njinswi ‘is a fish’.
Content 1: \gsrc mbúfù njínswì | \gll N-bufú nji-N-swí | \gls NP9-bream COP9-NP9-fish | \glt ‘A bream is a fish.’

Knowledge Point: To negate a copulative construction, the auxiliary verb ri ‘be’ is required in addition to the copulative prefix. This construction is discussed in Chapter \ref{bkm:Ref98752806} on negation.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Appositive prefixes are used on a noun, to mark the identity between the referent of the noun and the intended person, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref98835584}--\ref{bkm:Ref98835590}).
Content 1: \gsrc èmé ndènyòkò | \gll emé nde-∅-nyoko | \gls PERS1PL\- APP1SG-NP1a-your.mother | \glt ‘I, your mother…’
Content 2: \gsrc ènwé mùbáꜝnángù | \gll enwé mu-ba-án-angú | \gls PERS2PL APP2PL-NP2-child-POSS1SG | \glt ‘You, my children…’

Knowledge Point: Appositive prefixes may be combined with a co-referential personal pronoun, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref98835584}--\ref{bkm:Ref98835590}), or without a personal pronoun, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref71202998}--\ref{bkm:Ref71202999}).
Content 1: \gsrc èmé ndènyòkò | \gll emé nde-∅-nyoko | \gls PERS1PL\- APP1SG-NP1a-your.mother | \glt ‘I, your mother…’
Content 2: \gsrc ènwé mùbáꜝnángù | \gll enwé mu-ba-án-angú | \gls PERS2PL APP2PL-NP2-child-POSS1SG | \glt ‘You, my children…’
Content 3: \gsrc \textbf{tùbakêntù} kàtùnákùtíyàngà cáhà | \gll tu-ba-kéntu ka-tu-náku-tí-ang-a cahá | \gls APP1PL-NP2-woman NEG-SM1PL-HAB-FV very | \glt ‘\textbf{Us} \textbf{women}, we did not used to be afraid often.’
Content 4: \gsrc néwè òshùmékò \textbf{wènkômbwè} | \gll né=we o-shuHm-e=kó̲ we-∅-nkómbwe | \gls COM=PERS2SG SM2SG-bite-PFV.SBJV=LOC17 APP2SG-NP1a-tortoise | \glt ‘And you must also bite, \textbf{you} \textbf{tortoise}.’

Knowledge Point: The appositive prefixes are also used on the stem íni ‘self’, used as an emphatic reflexive; see (\ref{bkm:Ref492039232}--\ref{bkm:Ref492039233}) in \sectref{bkm:Ref451256199} on the reflexive.
Content 1: \gsrc ndìrìbwènè ndémwìnì | \gll ndi-riH-bweHne nde-mw-ini | \gls SM1SG-REFL-see.STAT APP1SG-NP1-owner | \glt ‘I see myself.’
Content 2: \gsrc twàkíbònì tùbênì | \gll tu-a-kí-bon-i tu-ba-íni | \gls SM1PL-PST-REFL-see-NPST.PFV APP1PL-NP2-self | \glt ‘We see ourselves.’

Knowledge Point: Adverbs in Fwe can be simplex or derived from other parts of speech with a derivational prefix ka-, bú- or mbó-. Adverbs can modify a verb, an adjective or another adverb, as illustrated with the adverb wâwà ‘very’ in (\ref{bkm:Ref98512678}--\ref{bkm:Ref498357438}).
Content 1: \gsrc èzí zìshámù zìgórétè wâwà | \gll e-zí zi-shamú zi-gor-é̲te wáwa | \gls AUG-DEM.I8 NP8-tree SM8-become_strong-STAT very | \glt ‘These trees are very strong.’
Content 2: \gsrc kàréː wâwà ndìnàmánì | \gll ka-réː wáwa ndi-na-man-í̲ | \gls ADV-long very SM1SG-PST-finish-NPST.PFV | \glt ‘I finished very long ago.’

Knowledge Point: Fwe has a small, closed set of words that typically function as adverbs, listed in (\ref{bkm:Ref71204521}).
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: The adverb câhà and its Zambian Fwe counterpart wâwà function as adverbs expressing general intensity, translatable as ‘very’, but can receive various more specific interpretations based on context, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref99025388}--\ref{bkm:Ref99025390}).
Content 1: \gsrc àbùtùká \textbf{câhà} | \gll a-buHtuk-á̲ cáha | \gls SM1-run-FV very | \glt ‘S/he runs \textbf{fast}.’
Content 2: \gsrc cìcíná cìrìmò ndìnàshînjì \textbf{wâwà} | \gll ci-ciná ci-rimo ndi-na-shínj-i wáwa | \gls EMPH7-DEM.IV7 NP7-year SM1SG-PST-harvest-NPST.PFV very | \glt ‘This year I had a \textbf{good} harvest.’

Knowledge Point: The prefix ka- derives an adverb from other words. Although this prefix resembles the class 12 nominal prefix ka- (see \sectref{bkm:Ref489005545} on nominal prefixes), this homophony is likely accidental: whereas the class 12 nominal prefix ka- replaces the noun’s original nominal prefix (see the examples in (\ref{bkm:Ref498357099}) in \sectref{bkm:Ref498357105}), the use of the adverb-deriving prefix ka- causes the noun’s original nominal prefix and augment to be maintained, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref71184200}--\ref{bkm:Ref71184201}).
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gsrc njékàndé ꜝryángù \textbf{kóbùfwîhì} | \gll njé-kandé rí-angú ká-o-bu-fwíi | \gls COP.DEF9-story PP5-POSS1SG ADV-AUG-NP14-short | \glt ‘This is my story, \textbf{in} \textbf{short}.’

Knowledge Point: The adverbial prefix ka- can be used to derive adverbs from nouns, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref71184200}--\ref{bkm:Ref71184201}), or from adjectives (\ref{bkm:Ref498357503}), infinitive verbs (\ref{bkm:Ref498417129}), or numerals (\ref{bkm:Ref498417486}).
Content 1: \gsrc njékàndé ꜝryángù \textbf{kóbùfwîhì} | \gll njé-kandé rí-angú ká-o-bu-fwíi | \gls COP.DEF9-story PP5-POSS1SG ADV-AUG-NP14-short | \glt ‘This is my story, \textbf{in} \textbf{short}.’
Content 2: Not found
Content 3: \gsrc ndìfwìrè \textbf{kànínì} ènjàrà | \gll ndi-fwH-ire ka-níni e-N-jara | \gls SM1SG-die-STAT ADV-small AUG-NP9-hunger | \glt ‘I’m \textbf{a} \textbf{bit} hungry.’
Content 4: \gsrc àkóːrà \textbf{kòkùóngòzà} | \gll a-kó̲ːr-a ka-o-ku-óngoz-a | \gls SM1-cough-FV ADV-AUG-INF-shout-FV | \glt ‘S/he coughs \textbf{loudly}.’
Content 5: \gsrc náàkóːrà \textbf{kòbírè} | \gll ná̲-a-a-kóːr-a ka-o=biré | \gls REM-SM1-PST-cough-FV ADV-CON=two | \glt ‘He coughed \textbf{twice}.’

Knowledge Point: The adverbial prefix ka- can be used to derive adverbs of manner, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref498357503}--\ref{bkm:Ref498417486}), but also temporal adverbs, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref98512719}--\ref{bkm:Ref98512721}).
Content 1: \gsrc ndìfwìrè \textbf{kànínì} ènjàrà | \gll ndi-fwH-ire ka-níni e-N-jara | \gls SM1SG-die-STAT ADV-small AUG-NP9-hunger | \glt ‘I’m \textbf{a} \textbf{bit} hungry.’
Content 2: \gsrc náàkóːrà \textbf{kòbírè} | \gll ná̲-a-a-kóːr-a ka-o=biré | \gls REM-SM1-PST-cough-FV ADV-CON=two | \glt ‘He coughed \textbf{twice}.’
Content 3: \gsrc zyônà nàndínàbúːkà \textbf{kàfôrù} | \gll zyóna na-ndí̲-na-búːk-a ka-fóru | \gls tomorrow REM-SM1SG-REM.FUT-wake-FV ADV-four | \glt ‘Tomorrow I will wake up \textbf{at} \textbf{four}.’
Content 4: \gsrc émè nándàréːtìwà \textbf{káꜝ}\textbf{náìntínsíkìsìtì} | \gll emé ná̲-ndi-a-réːt-iw-a ká-náintinsíkisiti | \gls PERS1SG REM-SM1SG-PST-bear-PASS-FV ADV-1960 | \glt ‘Me, I was born \textbf{in} \textbf{1960}.’

Knowledge Point: The prefix bú- derives manner adverbs. This prefix is similar to the nominal prefix of class 14 bu-, but the adverbial prefix has a high tone whereas the nominal prefix is toneless. The adverbial prefix bú- is productive, and can be used with adjectival roots, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref451866497}), and with verbs, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref451866458}).
Content 1: \gsrc àsèbèzá ꜝbúcènyà búcènyà | \gll a-sebez-á̲ bú-cenya bú-cenya | \gls SM1-work-FV ADV-small ADV-small | \glt ‘S/he works slowly.’
Content 2: \gsrc \label{bkm:Ref489957276}náàráːrà búꜝtútúmà | \glll ná̲-a-a-ráːr-a bú-tutum-á | \gls REM-SM1-PST-sleep-FV ADV-shiver-FV | \glt ‘She slept shivering.’

Knowledge Point: Adverbs derived from verbs maintain certain verbal characteristics: melodic tone (for instance, the final high tone on /bú-tutum-á/ in (\ref{bkm:Ref489957276})), and certain verbal affixes, such as the reflexive rí- and the stative suffix, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref451866568}). Adverbs derived from verbs can even take their own object, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref451866585}).
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gsrc tùkèrè búrìgùmbênè | \gll tu-keHre bú-riH-gumbé̲ne | \gls SM1PL-sit.STAT ADV-REFL-sit_close_to.STAT | \glt ‘We sit next to each other.’
Content 3: \gsrc ndìkèrè búrìyàngítè màkárà | \gll ndi-keHre bú-riH-ang-í̲te ma-kará | \gls SM1SG-sit.STAT ADV-REFL-cross-STAT NP6-leg | \glt ‘I sit cross-legged.’

Knowledge Point: There are also three underived adverbs that have the nominal prefix of class 14 bu-: bu-tí ‘how, so/like this’, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref99025443}) bu-ryó ‘only, just’, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref99025459}), and bu-ryahó ‘like that’, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref99025470}).
Content 1: \gsrc mbòndítêndè bútì kántì | \gll mbo-ndí̲-té̲nd-e bu-tí kantí | \gls NEAR.FUT-SM1SG-do-PFV.SBJV NP14-like_this then | \glt ‘I will do like this then.’
Content 2: \gsrc ndìyéndè bùryó ꜝkúmùnzì | \gll ndi-é̲nd-e bu-ryó kú-mu-nzi | \gls SM1SG-go-PFV.SBJV NP14-just NP17-NP3-village | \glt ‘Let me just go home.’
Content 3: \gsrc àhà bárèrè bùryáhò | \gll a-ha bá̲-reHre bu-ryahó | \gls AUG-DEM.I16 SM2.REL-sleep.STAT NP14-like_that | \glt ‘When they were sleeping like that…’

Knowledge Point: The prefix bu- in these adverbs is not the same as the productive adverbializer prefix bú-: it lacks a high tone, and functions as a nominal prefix, as seen from the fact that it may take a copulative prefix, either the homorganic nasal, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref490751209}), or the definite copulative prefix mbó- of class 14, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref490751210}) (see also \sectref{bkm:Ref489963307} on copulatives).
Content 1: \gsrc mbùryó ꜝndíꜝzánà | \gll N-bu-ryó ndí̲-zá̲n-a | \gls COP-NP14-only SM1SG.REL-joke-FV | \glt ‘I am only joking.’
Content 2: \gsrc mbóbùryàhó ꜝtúꜝkéːzyà | \gll mbó-bu-ryahó tú̲-ké̲ːzy-a | \gls COP.DEF14-NP14-like_that SM1PL.REL-come-FV | \glt ‘It is like that that we are coming.’

Knowledge Point: Adverbs can also be derived with the prefix mbó-, to express a comparison, translatable as ‘like’, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref99025559}--\ref{bkm:Ref99025561}).
Content 1: \gsrc àrírà mbómùcècè | \gll a-rir-á̲ mbó-mu-cece | \gls SM1-cry-FV ADV-NP1-baby | \glt ‘She cries like a baby.’
Content 2: Not found
